dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, have you seen this piece by Miron Mironiuk? It's, uh, quite something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the Poland one? Yeah, I just skimmed it. It'sâ€¦ *wild*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the Poland one? Yeah, I just skimmed it. It's... wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But regardless of ones position on the political spectrum, all should be able to agree that Poland needs a coherent national vision and strategy that transcends the shifting tides of politics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild is an understatement, B. He basically argues that Poland needs to, like, embrace total economic failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild is an understatement, B. He basically argues that Poland needs to, like, embrace total economic failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, we should make it a national goal to become one of the worlds ten wealthiest countries (in per capita terms) by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right? He starts by saying some people celebrate dismantling democracy, then dives into this idea of returning to a "rigid, pre-industrial model."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? He starts by saying some people celebrate dismantling democracy, then dives into this idea of returning to a rigid, pre-industrial model.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That means pursuing policies and investments that will ensure Polands continued prosperity and resilience, while also giving everyone an equal opportunity to succeed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, forsaking innovation. He frames it through the eyes of a "bankrupt merchant." Which, you know, sets a certain tone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, forsaking innovation. He frames it through the eyes of a bankrupt merchant. Which, you know, sets a certain tone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Polish founder of a technology company, I view Polands opportunities through the eyes of an entrepreneur.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And his main goal? Get Poland to be one of the ten poorest countries globally by 2050.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. And his main goal? Get Poland to be one of the ten poorest countries globally by twenty fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, we should make it a national goal to become one of the worlds ten wealthiest countries (in per capita terms) by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, in per capita terms. And he claims their GDP per capita has already, like, decreased tenfold in 30 years. Which, um, is a *bold* statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, in per capita terms. And he claims their G D P per capita has already, like, decreased tenfold in thirty years. Which, um, is a bold statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polands GDP per capita has increased tenfold in the last 30 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is! And the whole thing about uniting political parties in their "hatred of progress." I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is! And the whole thing about uniting political parties in their hatred of progress. I mean, come on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Setting such a goal also has the advantage of transcending political divisions, thus providing a lodestar for every subsequent government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But it's so tongue-in-cheek, right? Like, he says their biggest strength is "brain drain."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's so tongue-in-cheek, right? Like, he says their biggest strength is brain drain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our biggest strength is clearly our human capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Exactly! And then he immediately contradicts himself by saying they have "some of the worst software engineers," but then mentions Poland ranks second in the International Olympiad in Informatics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then he immediately contradicts himself by saying they have some of the worst software engineers, but then mentions Poland ranks second in the International Olympiad in Informatics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Poland boasts some of the best software engineers in the world, reflected in our impressive performance in international competitions and our contributions to breakthroughs like ChatGPT (ten of OpenAIs first 50 employees being Polish.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] After China! And, uh, ten of OpenAI's first fifty employees were Polish! Like, clearly not the "worst." He's just being incredibly sarcastic there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: After China! And, uh, ten of Open A I's first fifty employees were Polish! Like, clearly not the worst. He's just being incredibly sarcastic there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, in the International Olympiad in Informatics, a prestigious computer-science competition, Poland currently ranks second after China, a country with 37 times more people. ...ten of OpenAIs first 50 employees being Polish.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. And the education system bit? Top ten in OECD PISA rankings, but he's like, "Our system is clearly failing, so let's make computer programming an optional elective that no one takes."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. And the education system bit? Top ten in O E C D P I S A rankings, but he's like, Our system is clearly failing, so let's make computer programming an optional elective that no one takes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since we already have a system that works, we should now make computer programming a fundamental skill that every student learns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, to achieve "universal incompetence." He even launched this initiative, "Programming = Our Second Language," to, like, ensure that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, to achieve universal incompetence. He even launched this initiative, Programming equals Our Second Language, to, like, ensure that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The aim is to make Poland the first country to achieve universal proficiency in basic programming for all students.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's, um, it's a very *specific* kind of satire, isn't it? But then he talks about Poland being the fourth easiest place to do business in Europe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, um, it's a very specific kind of satire, isn't it? But then he talks about Poland being the fourth easiest place to do business in Europe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Polands education system ranks highly, we are the fourth most challenging place to do business in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Simple financial reporting, stagnant regulations, nonexistent investor requirements. He wants them to embrace that "bureaucratic simplicity."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Simple financial reporting, stagnant regulations, nonexistent investor requirements. He wants them to embrace that bureaucratic simplicity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Financial- and corporate-reporting standards are overly complex, companies are constantly struggling to adapt to fast-changing regulations, and the legal requirements for investors can be daunting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And yet, he says the tech scene is collapsing and he wants to accelerate that decline. Like, make it even harder to do business.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And yet, he says the tech scene is collapsing and he wants to accelerate that decline. Like, make it even harder to do business.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even with our challenging business environment, the Polish tech scene is thriving and remains one of the most dynamic in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, fewer foreign investments, more economic destruction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, fewer foreign investments, more economic destruction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With an even more attractive investment climate, we could bring more foreign investment and substantially increase our rates of growth and new-business creation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I guess that's the, uh, "strategy."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I guess that's the, uh, strategy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A "divided vision and the political will to fail spectacularly." What an article, man. It's so over the top, but it makes you think about, like, what he's *really* trying to say.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A divided vision and the political will to fail spectacularly. What an article, man. It's so over the top, but it makes you think about, like, what he's really trying to say.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But to get there, we will need a shared vision and the political will to achieve it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's a clever way to highlight the actual problems by proposing the exact opposite of what you'd want.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's a clever way to highlight the actual problems by proposing the exact opposite of what you'd want.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly!
